snippet: Prospects for an orderly NATO withdrawal from Afghanistan suffered two setbacks as President Hamid Karzai demanded limits on United States troops and the Taliban halted peace talks.
abstract: President Hamid Karzai insists that the United States confine its troops to major bases in Afghanistan by 2013 as the Taliban announces suspension of peace talks with the Americans, both of which serve to complicate the Obama administration’s plans for an orderly exit from the country; Afghan and American officials scramble to put the best possible face on yet another rift, which is coming at what both hope will be a final stage in negotiations between their diplomats on a long-term strategic partnership.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND, ELISABETH BUMILLER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Rod Nordland and Matthew Rosenberg reported from Kabul, and Elisabeth Bumiller from Kabul and Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

lead_paragraph: Prospects for an orderly NATO withdrawal from Afghanistan suffered two setbacks as President Hamid Karzai demanded limits on United States troops and the Taliban halted peace talks.

headline.seo: Karzai Wants U.S. Troops Confined to Bases; Taliban Suspend Peace Talks
headline.main: Karzai Calls on U.S. to Pull Back as Taliban Cancel Talks
headline.print_headline: Karzai Insisting On U.S. Pullback To Bases By 2013
